statement:
Let $\mathcal{F}$ be a Sperner family, that is, the collection of
subsets of $\{1,2,\dotsc,n\}$ such that no set contains any other
subset. Then
$$\sum_{X\in\mathcal{F}} \frac{1}{\binom{n}{{\left\lvert X\right\rvert}}}\leq 1.$$
This inequality is known as *LYM inequality* by the names of three
people that independently discovered it: Lubell[@cite:lubell_lym],
Yamamoto[@cite:yamamoto_lym], Meshalkin[@cite:meshalkin_lym].

Since $\binom{n}{k}\leq \binom{n}{{\left\lfloor n/2\right\rfloor}}$ for
every integer $k$, LYM inequality tells us that
